question.body:

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

question.title: Given Ted Cruz is the Republican nominee, will Donald Trump be removed from any primary ballot under the 14th Amendment?
question.body:

Then, is it true that Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024?

Resolution criteria for the outcome: This question will resolve as "Yes" if, on July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]

"""

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Joe Biden will remain President through the end of July 2024, I will consider several factors that could influence his ability to continue in office. Firstly, Joe Biden's age is a significant factor. He will be 82 years old by the end of July 2024, which is relatively old for a President. While there is no direct correlation between age and presidential tenure, it is worth noting that some presidents have faced health issues or cognitive decline as they have aged. Secondly, Joe Biden's health has been a subject of public concern in the past. He has been open about his struggles with stuttering, and there have been reports of him experiencing cognitive decline. However, it is worth noting that he has also been open about his health and has undergone regular medical check-ups. Thirdly, the 25th Amendment to the US Constitution allows for the temporary transfer of power to the Vice President in the event of the President's incapacitation. This could potentially allow Biden to remain in office even if he is unable to perform his duties. Considering these factors, I believe that the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 is relatively low, but not impossible.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Donald Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, I'll consider various factors that could influence this outcome. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment disqualifies individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. Given Trump's role in the January 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol attack, there is a possibility that some states might invoke this provision to remove or block him from their primary election ballots. However, there are several reasons to believe that this might not happen: 1. The 14th Amendment's Section 3 disqualification clause has only been used once in U.S. history, and that was in the case of former Confederate officials after the Civil War. 2. The clause's application to Trump would require a state to determine that he engaged in insurrection or rebellion, which might be a challenging and contentious process. 3. Trump's supporters and allies might contest any attempts to remove or block him from the ballot, leading to potential legal battles and delays. 4. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after July 15, 2024, which could further complicate the outcome. Considering these factors, I would assess the likelihood of Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as relatively low.

Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden does not announce before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President. This means there is no definitive, public, official announcement from Biden or his campaign indicating that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination for another term as President in the 2024 cycle.

Given this scenario, will Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average? This question will resolve based on the value reported on 538's national polling average chart for the date of July 15, 2024, accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value indicates a Trump lead, while a negative value indicates a Biden lead. For example, a value of 2.4 means Trump is 2.4 points ahead of Biden.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To determine the probability that Trump's lead over Biden will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, we need to consider the implications of Joe Biden not announcing before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination. This scenario implies that Biden's candidacy status is uncertain, which can lead to increased uncertainty and volatility in the polls. In this context, the 538 national polling average is likely to reflect this uncertainty, and the lead of Trump over Biden could be affected by various factors such as voter sentiment, campaign strategies, and external events. However, given the uncertainty surrounding Biden's candidacy, it is likely that the polling average will be closer to zero, reflecting the competitive nature of the election. Considering these factors, I would expect the lead of Trump over Biden to be relatively close to zero, rather than being greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3. However, it is possible that the polling average could be volatile and reflect a larger lead for Trump, especially given the uncertainty surrounding Biden's candidacy.

question.title: Will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Liz Cheney will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider the current political landscape and the factors that influence the outcome of the Republican National Convention. Firstly, Liz Cheney's current standing within the Republican Party is not strong. She has been a vocal critic of former President Trump, which has made her unpopular among many Republican voters. In 2021, she was removed from her leadership position in the House Republican Conference, and in 2022, she lost her primary election in Wyoming. These incidents suggest that her popularity within the party is waning. Secondly, the Republican National Convention is typically more conservative than the general Republican electorate. The convention delegates are often more loyal to the party's conservative wing and may favor candidates who align with their views. Given Liz Cheney's moderate to liberal stance on certain issues, it's possible that the delegates may not favor her as their nominee. Lastly, the Republican field for the 2024 presidential election is likely to be crowded and competitive. Other candidates, such as Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and Nikki Haley, may have a stronger appeal to the party's conservative base and may be more likely to secure the nomination. Considering these factors, it seems unlikely that Liz Cheney will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

Considering these factors, I believe that the probability of Joe Biden announcing before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President is relatively low.

question.body:

If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, I will consider various factors that might influence this outcome. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment allows for the removal or denial of a person's right to hold federal office if they have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. This provision has been interpreted to apply to individuals who have supported or participated in the January 6, 2021, US Capitol attack. There are several reasons why I think it is unlikely that Donald Trump will be removed from the primary election ballot: 1. Lack of concrete evidence: While there is ongoing debate about whether Trump's actions on January 6, 2021, constitute insurrection, there is no concrete evidence that would directly link Trump to the planning or execution of the attack. The House Select Committee on the January 6 Attack has made several recommendations for accountability, but these are not directly related to Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. 2. Legal hurdles: The process of removing or blocking a candidate from the ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment is complex and involves legal procedures that are not straightforward. State election officials and courts would need to agree that Trump's actions meet the criteria for removal, which is a high bar to clear. 3. Political considerations: Removing Trump from the ballot would be a highly political move, potentially sparking controversy and further polarization. State election officials and courts may be hesitant to take such a step, especially in the lead-up to the 2024 election. 4. Previous attempts at disqualification: There have been previous attempts to disqualify Trump from the ballot or otherwise prevent him from running, but these have been unsuccessful. This suggests that there may be a high threshold for removing him from the ballot. Considering these factors, I estimate the probability of Donald Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024, to be relatively low.

question.body:

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

First, Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution disqualifies individuals from holding public office if they have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. The grounds for removal or blockage from the primary election ballot are tied to this provision, which has been interpreted in various court cases and is subject to ongoing legal discussions. Given the current context, there is no conclusive evidence that suggests Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024. question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of a brokered convention for the Democrats in 2024, I'll consider several factors that could influence the likelihood of a brokered convention. A brokered convention typically occurs when there is no clear winner after the first round of voting, often due to a large number of candidates, a split among key voting blocks, or a strong candidate not securing the necessary delegates in the first round. First, I'll assess the current field of Democratic candidates. If there are many candidates with a strong following and a chance of securing a significant number of delegates, it increases the likelihood of a brokered convention. On the other hand, if there are fewer candidates or a clear front-runner, it decreases the likelihood. Next, I'll consider the potential for a strong candidate not securing the necessary delegates in the first round. This could happen if a candidate's support is concentrated in a few states or if they face significant opposition from other strong candidates. Lastly, I'll evaluate the party's rules and the potential for a shift in the nomination process. Changes in the party's nomination process or a shift in the political landscape could impact the likelihood of a brokered convention. Given these considerations, I assess the situation as follows: There are currently several candidates in the Democratic primary, but none have a clear lead. Some candidates have strong support in specific regions, which could lead to a split of delegates. Additionally, there have been no significant changes in the party's nomination process that would make a brokered convention more or less likely. However, the actual likelihood of a brokered convention remains low, as the Democratic Party has generally favored a more streamlined nomination process in recent years.

This question explores the relationship between two events:

1. **Condition**: The US government continues its agreement directly allowing Verisign to manage the authoritative domain name registry for the .com TLD, on or after August 3, 2024. This resolves as Yes if on or after August 3, 2024, the US Department of Commerce (DOC) has not officially terminated or sunset its Cooperative Agreement with Verisign recognizing Verisign's management of the *.com* generic top-level domain (TLD). If this does happen before August 3, 2024, this question resolves as No.

2. **Outcome**: Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President. This resolves as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive. If such a statement is not made prior to the deadline, this resolves as No.

Suppose the following is true: The US government continues its agreement with Verisign for the .com TLD management on or after August 3, 2024. Then, will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President?

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question explores the relationship between two events: the US government continuing its agreement with Verisign for .com TLD management on or after August 3, 2024, and Joe Biden announcing before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President. The condition is about the continuation of the agreement, while the outcome is about Biden's announcement. Given the condition is met (the agreement will continue), we need to assess the likelihood of the outcome (Biden announcing his non-acceptance of the nomination). To estimate the probability of Biden announcing his non-acceptance of the nomination, we need to consider several factors: Biden's current political situation and potential reasons for not seeking re-election, the timeline for announcing his non-acceptance of the nomination, and the likelihood of Biden's team making an official, public announcement. Considering these factors, I argue that the probability of Biden announcing his non-acceptance of the nomination before July 15, 2024, is relatively low. While it's possible, there are no strong indications that he will not seek re-election, and his team may choose to keep their plans under wraps until the DNC. Therefore, I estimate the probability of the question resolving as YES as 0.05.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is a conditional forecast, which means its resolution depends on the outcome of another question (P) and the outcome of interest (Q). I'll analyze the two components separately. First, for the condition (P), I consider the likelihood that ISS advises against Elon Musk's package or Kimbal Musk's re-election. Given the context of Elon Musk's pay package and Kimbal Musk's re-election, it's reasonable to assume that ISS has evaluated these proposals. I would assign a relatively high probability to ISS releasing an advisory statement, which resolves the condition (P). Second, for the outcome of interest (Q), I consider the likelihood that the linked market gets at least 377 traders by July 15. The market size is determined by the number of active traders in the linked market. This outcome is influenced by various factors, such as market conditions, the embedded market's characteristics, and user engagement. While I can't predict the exact market size, I would assume that the embedded market has some level of user engagement and activity. A market size of at least 377 traders by July 15 seems plausible, but it's also a specific target, which implies some uncertainty. Now, considering the conditional structure of the question, the probability of the linked market getting at least 377 traders by July 15 given that ISS advises against Elon Musk's package or Kimbal Musk's re-election is related to the joint probability of the two components. I would use a logical framework to break down the probability: Let P(P) be the probability that ISS advises against Elon Musk's package or Kimbal Musk's re-election (condition resolved YES). Let P(Q|P) be the probability that the linked market gets at least 377 traders by July 15 given that ISS advises against Elon Musk's package or Kimbal Musk's re-election. The joint probability is P(P and Q) = P(P) * P(Q|P). To estimate the conditional probability P(Q|P), I would need more information about the relationship between ISS's advisory statements and the market size of the linked market. Without such information, I'll make a rough estimate, assuming that the market size is somewhat independent of the ISS advisory. Given these considerations, I would estimate the probability of the condition (P) being resolved as around 0.6 (60% likelihood of ISS advising against either proposal). For the conditional probability P(Q|P), I would estimate around 0.4 (40% likelihood of the linked market getting at least 377 traders by July 15 given that ISS advises against either proposal). This is a rough estimate, considering the uncertainty around the market size and its dependence on various factors. Combining these probabilities using the logical framework, I get: P(P and Q) = P(P) * P(Q|P) = 0.6 * 0.4 = 0.24. Therefore, I estimate the probability that the linked market gets at least 377 traders by July 15 given that ISS advises against Elon Musk's package or Kimbal Musk's re-election as approximately 0.24.

question.title: Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024, the [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any of the following categories:



- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine

- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Assessed Russian Control

- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location



The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:



- Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives

- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, I consider the following factors: 1. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment: This section disqualifies individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. The amendment was ratified in 1868, and its application to Donald Trump, who was involved in the January 6, 2021, Capitol riot, is a matter of debate. However, some legal scholars argue that Trump's actions could be considered an insurrection or rebellion, which would make him eligible for removal under Section 3. 2. Legal precedents: There are no clear legal precedents for applying Section 3 to a former president. However, there are some cases where individuals have been removed from office under similar circumstances, such as the 1869 impeachment of Andrew Johnson. 3. Current legal battles: There are ongoing legal battles regarding the application of Section 3 to Donald Trump. Some states, such as Arizona and New Mexico, have already removed Trump from their primary election ballots, while others, such as Florida and Texas, have not. 4. Political climate: The political climate in the United States is highly polarized, and the issue of Trump's eligibility for office is highly contested. Some politicians and legal experts argue that Trump's actions on January 6, 2021, were an insurrection or rebellion, while others argue that they were not. Considering these factors, I estimate that the probability of Donald Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment is around 0.4 (40%). This is because while there are some legal and political arguments in favor of removing Trump, there are also significant obstacles and uncertainties surrounding the application of Section 3.

question.title: Given Donald Trump is not removed from any primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, will Russia control Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has not been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. There are no official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports confirming such a removal or block. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has not been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves affirmatively.

Then, is it true that on June 1, 2024, the Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any of the following categories: Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine, Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours, Assessed Russian Control, Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine, or any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location? The question will resolve as **Yes** if the location is in any of these categories indicating Russian control, and **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to: Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours, Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives, Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare, or any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This question involves two distinct parts: the removal of Donald Trump from primary election ballots under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment and the control of Chasiv Yar by Russia as of June 1, 2024, based on the ISW map. First, we need to establish the likelihood of Donald Trump not being removed from any primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024. Given the strict criteria for resolution (official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports), it's reasonable to assume that without any such announcements or reports by July 15, 2024, Trump would not be removed. This seems like a low-risk scenario, as the question specifies that speculative reports or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. Next, we consider the likelihood that on June 1, 2024, the ISW map shows Chasiv Yar under any categories indicating Russian control. This requires knowledge of the ongoing conflict in Ukraine and the status of Chasiv Yar as of June 1, 2024. Given that the question is asking about a specific date in the future (June 1, 2024) and the ISW map is a potential source of information, we must rely on available data and trends up to the resolution date (July 15, 2024). However, without access to real-time information or the ability to predict future events, we can only base our estimates on general knowledge and trends up to the resolution date. As of the resolution date, Chasiv Yar is a city in eastern Ukraine that has been affected by the conflict. The ISW map is a reliable source of information on the conflict, but its categories indicating Russian control are subject to change based on the evolving situation in Ukraine. Given the uncertainty surrounding the conflict and the potential for changes in the situation, it's challenging to provide a definitive estimate for the likelihood of Russia controlling Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024. However, considering the strict criteria for resolution and the need for official announcements or reports, the likelihood of Trump not being removed from primary election ballots seems relatively high.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Trump's lead over Biden will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, I will consider the following factors: 1. Historical trends: The 2024 presidential election is still over a year away, and polling numbers can fluctuate significantly over time. However, we can look at past election cycles to see if there are any patterns or trends that might inform our estimate. 2. Current polling: As of my knowledge cutoff, the 538 national polling average shows a relatively stable lead for Trump over Biden. However, this lead is within a narrow margin, and it's possible that the gap could widen or narrow in the coming months. 3. Election dynamics: The 2024 presidential election will be influenced by a range of factors, including the candidates' campaigns, the state of the economy, and external events like global conflicts or natural disasters. These factors can impact polling numbers and make it difficult to predict with certainty. 4. 538's polling model: 538's national polling average is a weighted average of multiple polls, which helps to smooth out fluctuations and provide a more stable estimate of the candidates' relative support. However, this model is not perfect, and there may be biases or errors that affect the accuracy of the results. Considering these factors, I believe that Trump's lead over Biden on July 15, 2024, will likely be within a narrow range, but it's difficult to predict with certainty whether it will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3.

This reflects my assessment that Trump is a strong contender for the nomination, but that there are also some uncertainties and potential challenges that could impact his chances.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Trump will gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents, we need to consider the following factors: 1. The fact that public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error. This suggests that Manifold respondents may be more conservative or Republican-leaning compared to the general public. 2. The fact that the question is asking about a specific voter choice (voting for Joe Biden) vs. a generic Democrat, which may elicit different responses from respondents. A generic Democrat may be perceived as more palatable to some voters who might not be enthusiastic about Joe Biden specifically. 3. The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is based on a simple ratio of Trump's votes to the total number of votes. This formula does not account for other factors that may influence voting behavior, such as demographics, party affiliation, or issue positions. Considering these factors, it's possible that Manifold respondents may be more likely to vote for Trump when given the option to vote for Joe Biden specifically, rather than a generic Democrat. This could be due to a variety of reasons, such as a stronger emotional attachment to Trump or a perception that voting for Biden is a 'lesser of two evils.' However, it's also possible that the difference in voting behavior between the two polls may be minimal, and the 3% threshold may not be met. Based on these considerations, I estimate the probability that Trump will gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents to be around 60%. This is a moderate estimate, reflecting the uncertainty surrounding the outcome and the potential for a range of responses from respondents.

question.title: Given Trump gains at least 3% among Manifold respondents facing Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for 2024?

question.title: Before July 1, 2024, will the International Criminal Court issue arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if before July 1, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues a [warrant of arrest](https://www.icc-cpi.int/about/how-the-court-works) for any of the below listed Israeli cabinet members. It will resolve as **No** otherwise.

* Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister)
* Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
* Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of the International Criminal Court (ICC) issuing arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders before July 1, 2024, I'll consider the following factors: 1. The ICC's track record: The ICC has issued arrest warrants in the past for individuals accused of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide. While it has focused on situations in Africa and other regions, it has also investigated and prosecuted cases involving non-state parties and individuals. 2. The nature of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict: The conflict is a longstanding and complex issue, with both sides accusing each other of war crimes and human rights abuses. The ICC has been investigating the situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territory since 2009, and there have been reports of potential war crimes committed by both Israeli and Palestinian parties. 3. Recent developments: In recent years, there have been several high-profile cases involving Israeli officials being investigated or charged with war crimes, including the case of former Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert being investigated for war crimes in the 2002 Jenin refugee camp. However, these cases have been slow-moving and often stalled. 4. The ICC's current investigations: The ICC has been investigating the situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territory since 2009, and in 2021, it opened an investigation into alleged war crimes committed by Israeli forces in the Gaza Strip during the 2014 conflict. However, the investigation has been slow to progress. 5. The ICC's jurisdiction: The ICC has jurisdiction over war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide, but only if the crimes were committed after July 1, 2002. Since the conflict in the Occupied Palestinian Territory began before this date, the ICC's jurisdiction is limited to crimes committed after 2002. Considering these factors, while there are valid reasons to believe the ICC might issue arrest warrants for some Israeli leaders, the process of issuing warrants is often slow and subject to various legal and political considerations. The ICC has a history of taking years to issue warrants, and the Israeli government has been known to resist ICC investigations and prosecutions. Given these considerations, I estimate the probability of the ICC issuing arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders before July 1, 2024, as relatively low.

Suppose the following is true: No terrorist attack in metropolitan France injures and/or kills at least one person, other than the terrorist(s), between, and inclusive of, the day of the Opening Ceremony (26 July 2024) and the day of the Closing Ceremony (11 August 2024). An event is considered a 'terrorist attack' if it is described as such by any agency of the State of France, or by the French President, Prime Minister, or a member of the Council of Ministers.

Then, will the International Criminal Court (ICC) issue a warrant of arrest for any of the following Israeli cabinet members before July 1, 2024?

* Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister)
* Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
* Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

Resolution criteria: Resolves YES if the ICC issues a warrant of arrest for any of the listed Israeli leaders before July 1, 2024. Resolves NO otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around the potential actions of the International Criminal Court (ICC) in relation to Israeli leaders, contingent on the absence of terrorist attacks during the 2024 Summer Olympics in metropolitan France. Given the political complexities and the historical context of international law, it is unlikely that the ICC would issue arrest warrants for the listed Israeli leaders before July 1, 2024. The timing of the Olympics and the political climate surrounding Israel and the ICC may influence the likelihood of such warrants being issued. Therefore, I assess the probability of the ICC issuing arrest warrants for the listed Israeli leaders as low, given the conditions specified.

question.title: Will Donald Trump testify at the hush money trial?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) report Donald Trump has testified, whether in person or remotely, at the [trial](https://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/webcrim_attorney/Detail?which=case&docketNumber=q23XFOwZRDQ1d4LrNRdw2clqCMt/CzUoG/kRII/7Nmg=&countyId=K4i18rFVPQh5HTQ/kUoO3Q==&docketId=3Y4iKU5oHM75AtDme2cPhw==&docketDseq=T/O1YN_PLUS_BG65HkOeqEnpAkw==&defendantName=TRUMP,+DONALD&court=New+York+Supreme+Criminal+Court&courtType=U&recordType=U&recordNum=) concerning the so-called "hush money" payments to Stormy Daniels.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Donald Trump will testify at the hush money trial, I need to consider various factors that might influence his decision to testify. Firstly, it's essential to understand that Trump has a history of being involved in high-profile trials and has often been known to take a confrontational approach. This suggests that he might be willing to testify in his own defense, especially if he believes it will help his case or boost his public image. However, it's also worth noting that Trump's lawyers have often employed a strategy of avoiding direct confrontations with prosecutors and the media. This could indicate that they might advise Trump to avoid testifying, especially if they believe it could lead to potentially damaging testimony. question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?

Lack of precedent: There is no precedent for a President being declared incapacitated under Section 4, which makes it difficult to estimate the likelihood of such an event occurring. question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

Jared Huffman (D-Calif.). This suggests that there is a significant amount of opposition within the Democratic party to the early nomination plan. Additionally, the fact that the letter has been circulated and is being discussed publicly indicates that there is a degree of organization and effort behind the opposition. However, it's worth noting that the resolution of the market is based on the number of signatures by market close on July 21st, and the market resolves to NO if the criteria are not met by this time. Given that the resolution date is July 23rd, there is still some time left for more signatures to be added. However, considering the current level of opposition and the time remaining, it seems unlikely that the market will resolve to YES. Therefore, I would estimate the probability of the question resolving YES as 0.2.

question.title: Given Joe Biden announces he will not accept the Democratic nomination, will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President. This occurs if Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to this effect, leaving no room for the possibility of accepting the nomination.

Then, is it true that Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model? This resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is greater than 46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

metadata.chain_of_thought: If Joe Biden announces that he won't accept the Democratic nomination, Kamala Harris would likely become the nominee. In this scenario, Nate Silver's model would likely reweight the polls to reflect Harris as the new nominee, rather than Biden. Given that Harris is generally considered to be less popular than Biden, and that there is a significant gap between her and the other top Democratic candidates in the polls, it's likely that her odds of winning would decrease in the model. Therefore, it's unlikely that her odds of winning would increase according to Nate Silver's model after Biden's announcement.

question.title: Given Joe Biden does not announce he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination, will Kamala's odds of winning increase according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden does not make a definitive, public, official announcement before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. Given this, will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?

Resolution criteria:
- For the condition: Resolves YES if Joe Biden or his campaign does not make such an announcement by the specified time. Resolves NO if such an announcement is made.
- For the outcome: Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday, August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought: If Joe Biden does not make a definitive, public, official announcement before July 15, 2024, that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination, it is likely that Kamala Harris's odds of winning will increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model. This is because the lack of such an announcement would likely be seen as a sign of uncertainty or weakness on Biden's part, potentially benefiting Harris's chances. Additionally, the resolution criteria specify that the Electoral College probability for Harris must be >46.6% on August 9th at 8:40 PM for the outcome to resolve as YES, which suggests that the model is likely to increase Harris's odds over time.

This approach helps to reduce noise and provide a more accurate representation of public opinion. 3. However, I can rely on general trends and the fact that polling averages tend to converge over time. 4. Considering these factors, I'll make an educated estimate based on general trends and the complexity of polling data. question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the likelihood of Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024, we must examine the circumstances surrounding this invocation. First, Section 4 explicitly requires a bipartisan consensus between the Vice President and a majority of Cabinet members. Considering the heightened political tensions in the 2024 context, along with a notable increase of discussions on this amendment concerning President Biden's presidency after a specific political action; the process outlined is sufficiently rigorous and involves not simply the president or political rivals, but other powerful elements of government and constitutional leaders. question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

The fact that Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) is involved in the effort and has circulated a drafted letter suggests that there is a significant amount of opposition within the party. Additionally, the language used by Huffman in the interview, such as calling the DNC's move 'a really bad move' and stating that it 'doesn't work that way', implies a strong sense of disagreement among some Democrats. However, it's difficult to estimate the exact number of signatures that will be gathered, and there may be other factors at play that could affect the outcome. Nevertheless, given the evidence of organized opposition, I would lean towards a higher probability of at least 20 House/Senate Democrats signing a public letter opposing the plan.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Democrats having a brokered convention in 2024, I'll consider the factors that influence the likelihood of a brokered convention. A brokered convention typically occurs when no candidate has a majority of the delegates before the convention, leading to multiple rounds of voting. This can happen if there is a large field of candidates, a lack of a clear front-runner, and a complex delegate allocation system. In the 2024 US presidential election, the Democratic Party has a relatively large field of candidates, with over 20 individuals having expressed interest in running. This increases the likelihood of a brokered convention. Additionally, the delegate allocation system is complex, with multiple states having different allocation methods, which can lead to a situation where no candidate has a clear majority. However, there are also factors that could reduce the likelihood of a brokered convention. For example, some candidates may drop out early, potentially leading to a clearer front-runner. Furthermore, the Democratic Party has implemented reforms aimed at reducing the likelihood of a brokered convention, such as the 'Unity Commission' recommendations, which aim to increase the number of delegates needed to win the nomination. Given these factors, I estimate the probability of a brokered convention as follows: I think it's more likely than not that the Democratic Party will not have a brokered convention in 2024, but there's still a non-negligible chance of it happening. I'm assigning a probability of 0.4, indicating a moderate likelihood.

question.title: Will Fidesz-KDNP Maintain Its EU Plurality from Hungary in 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve to "Yes" if, following the 2024 European Parliament elections, the Fidesz-KDNP alliance secures more seats than any other single party or coalition, thereby maintaining the highest number of Hungarian seats in the European Parliament, according to credible sources.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Fidesz-KDNP will maintain its EU plurality from Hungary in 2024, I'll consider several factors that could influence the outcome of the European Parliament elections. Firstly, Fidesz-KDNP has been the ruling party in Hungary since 2010 and has maintained a strong grip on power. However, the party has faced significant criticism from the EU for its handling of democratic norms, the rule of law, and human rights. This criticism has led to the EU imposing sanctions on Hungary and potentially weakening the party's popularity. Secondly, the opposition in Hungary is fragmented, with several parties competing against Fidesz-KDNP. However, the opposition has gained momentum in recent years, and some polls suggest that they could potentially gain seats in the European Parliament. Thirdly, the European Parliament elections are often considered a second-order national election, meaning that they are less important than national elections and can be influenced by a variety of factors, including the popularity of the ruling party, the state of the European economy, and the performance of the incumbent MEPs. Considering these factors, I estimate that Fidesz-KDNP has a moderate chance of maintaining its EU plurality from Hungary in 2024. The party's strong grip on power and its ability to mobilize its supporters could help it maintain its position. However, the opposition's growing momentum and the EU's criticism of the party's policies could potentially erode its support. Therefore, I assign a probability of 0.55 to the question resolving 'Yes'.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]
question.body:
Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie.
https://deepnewz.com/movies/deadpool-wolverine-set-record-360m-global-opening-weekend-biggest-r-rated-debut

"""

The film, directed by Shawn Levy and starring Ryan Reynolds, is projected to earn between $340 million and $360 million globally in its opening weekend. This would mark the biggest opening weekend ever for an R-rated movie. Domestically, the film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time.

"""

[image]The record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is the original Deadpool at $284.5M ($152.2M domestic).

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

[image]
Will the new movie top these marks? It will probably be close...

It will certainly play at more theaters... Deadpool was a smash hit at the time, and a bit surprising.

Since BoxOfficeMojo is a bit weird on reporting international opening weekends -- it provides the raw numbers but aggregates them weirdly -- we will wait for Hollywood Reporter to let us know what the weekend opening was.

To clarify on resolution...
-> this market will resolve YES if Deadpool x Wolverine grosses more than $284.5M globally this opening weekend according to reports
-> AND the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

question.title: Will Greens–EFA hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the Greens–EFA political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other outcomes. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that the Greens–EFA will hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, I consider several factors. Firstly, the Greens–EFA has been gaining popularity in recent years, particularly among younger voters and in environmentally concerned demographics. This trend suggests that they may continue to gain support in the upcoming elections. However, the European Parliament elections are complex, with many factors influencing voter behavior, such as national politics, economic conditions, and global events. Additionally, the Greens–EFA faces competition from other left-wing and green parties, which may erode their share of the vote. Furthermore, the European Parliament's electoral system is proportional representation, which can lead to fragmentation and make it difficult for any single group to achieve a majority. Given these complexities, it's challenging to make a definitive prediction. However, considering the Greens–EFA's growing popularity and the potential for them to capitalize on the environmental and social concerns of European voters, I assign a moderate probability to them holding the most seats.

question.body:

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?

This can happen if there is a strong split among the party's factions, or if no clear front-runner emerges. Several factors suggest that a brokered convention is unlikely: 1.
